intro: Lippia turbinata f. angustifolia, commonly known as narrow-leaf turpentine bush, is a flowering plant native to the southern United States and northern Mexico. It is a member of the Verbenaceae family and is characterized by its aromatic, narrow leaves and small, tubular flowers. The plant typically grows in dry, sunny habitats such as woodlands and grasslands. Its leaves are often used in traditional medicine for their purported antimicrobial and anti-inflammatory properties. The species is also valued in horticulture for its ornamental appeal and ability to thrive in arid conditions.
